paragraphs.text: Student arrested after teacher takes smartphone: Do our devices own us?
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: Last Tuesday, a ninth-grader at John F  Kennedy High School in Paterson, N.J , was caught on video throwing his 62-year-old teacher to the ground and wrestling with him in order to retrieve his cellphone
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: which the teacher had confiscated
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Teachers at the school allow cellphones to be used for educational purposes in the classroom
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: they may take them and hold them until the end of class
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: if
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: a student appears to be using his phone for any other purpose
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Granted
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the boy may have demonstrated problems controlling his impulses in other settings, too
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the video of his attack has resulted in national attention
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: And
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: that's because it isn't the first dramatic example of how attached to our phones we have become
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Last year, a Houston woman was shot by a mugger when she refused to hand over her cellphone
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: She survived
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: she later asserted that she had done the right thing
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: In 2013, a 22-year-old man was killed by a train when he tried to retrieve the cellphone he had dropped on the tracks
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Without giving a great deal of thought to the psychological implications,
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: our species has deployed mobile technology very quickly, in a very widespread manner
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: One reason is that the marketplace embraced smartphones in an astounding way
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: as if our phones and their apps are a lock-and-key fit with our psyches
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: According to one source, there are 7 billion mobile devices on earth, one for almost each person
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: What is "in" our cellphones that would lead people to attack others or risk death to keep them?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: I would argue that the phones absorb and record our thoughts and intentions so dramatically that we become unconsciously convinced they are "parts of us."
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Why else would so many people hesitate even to leave a room without taking their cellphones with them?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Why would they interrupt meetings and family time to check them?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Why would young people be opting to spend their money on newer, faster ones, instead of on clothing?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Why would there be so much interest in personalizing the sounds they make, the apps they hold and the cases that hold them?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: I contend we have already crossed the Rubicon, almost irrevocably incorporating technology into our psyches in a way that makes us part flesh and blood, part hardware
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The fact that the hardware is outside our bodies(for now) does not mean the integration has not occurred
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We are psychologically magnetized to our devices
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: That's why some people will fight for them, and even die for them
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The selfie has become so ubiquitous that it no longer seems bizarre to see someone smiling into a cellphone or sticking out her tongue or making a sad face -- acting-- and then snapping a photo
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: And these images are then sent not only to her supposed "friends," who may number in the hundreds, but also to her unconscious mind -- reinforcing the idea that she is what her cellphone records her to be
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Take away the cellphone and, in some measure, she believes she disappears
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: She feels she dies a little bit, or more than a little bit, psychologically
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The business of selling "selfie sticks"-- telescoping rods that hold a cellphone far enough away to facilitate a really good shot-- is robust enough to make many retailers place large kiosks of them near the checkout register
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Cellphones, you might say, are growing arms
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Ours apparently aren't long enough
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This is just the beginning
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Cellphones will soon be able to determine whether you are looking at the content on their screens, rather than looking away
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: They will demand attention
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The extent to which we own them versus them owning us will be increasingly in doubt
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Make no mistake
paragraphs.label: other

paragraphs.text: While
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: technology can be good when harnessed for the good
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: (raising money for charity occurs to me)
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: there will be hell to pay for giving so little thought to the downside
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: That downside likely includes an epidemic of narcissism in young people, increased rates of anxiety and dramatically decreased feelings of autonomy
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Because to the extent that one's self-image is outsourced to a mobile device, it is no more deeply rooted than that
paragraphs.label: assumption
